expanded_description: Compound inequalities involve two separate inequalities joined by the words 'and' or 'or'. 'And' compound inequalities require that a value satisfy both inequalities simultaneously—the solution is the intersection of the two solution sets. These are often written in compact form as $a < x < b$ and represent values between two endpoints.

core_concept.principle: An 'and' compound inequality, such as $x > 2$ and $x < 5$, means that $x$ must satisfy both conditions. The solution is the set of values that are greater than 2 AND less than 5, which can be written compactly as $2 < x < 5$. Graphically, this is the overlapping region on a number line—the values between the two endpoints.
core_concept.explanation: Think of 'and' compound inequalities as a bouncer at a club checking two requirements: you must be at least 18 AND have a valid ID. Both must be true. On a number line, it's like a fenced area between two fences—you're inside only if you're past the left fence AND before the right fence.

image.alt: Number line showing x > 2 and x < 5 with overlapping region shaded
image.caption: Figure 6.6.1: AND compound inequality - intersection of two conditions.

sections.introduction: An 'and' compound inequality combines two conditions that must both be true. The solution is where the two conditions overlap.

introduction_image.alt: Venn diagram showing intersection of two sets
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.6.2: AND means intersection - both conditions must be true.

key_concept.definition: A compound inequality with 'and' has the form $x > a$ and $x < b$ (or similar). The solution is the set of numbers that satisfy both inequalities. This can be written compactly as $a < x < b$. The graph is the region between $a$ and $b$ on the number line.
key_concept.context: AND inequalities represent constraints that must all be met—like temperature between freezing and boiling, or age between minimum and maximum for a contest.

image.alt: Number line showing x > 2 and x < 5 with overlap highlighted
image.caption: Figure 6.6.3: The solution is where both conditions are true.

characteristics: Can be written compactly as $a < x < b$

image.alt: Number line with x > 2 and x < 5 shown separately
image.caption: Figure 6.6.4: Separate inequalities before combining.

examples.explanation: Numbers greater than 2 AND less than 7: $2 < x < 7$

characteristics: Single inequality with variable in the middle
Endpoints may be inclusive or exclusive
classifications.behavior: Values strictly between a and b, or including endpoints.

image.alt: Number line with shading between 2 and 5
image.caption: Figure 6.6.5: Compact form: 2 < x < 5.

classifications.value: Endpoints may be included or excluded
characteristics: Mixed: $a < x \leq b$ or $a \leq x < b$
classifications.behavior: Whether endpoints are part of solution.

image.alt: Number lines showing different endpoint types
image.caption: Figure 6.6.6: Different endpoint combinations.

worked_examples.title: Identifying AND Compound Inequalities

image.alt: Various inequality statements
image.caption: Figure 6.6.7: Identify which are AND compound inequalities.

worked_examples.problem:
Which of the following are AND compound inequalities? For those that are, write them in compact form.
a) $x > 3$ and $x < 8$
b) $x < -2$ or $x > 4$
c) $x \geq 0$ and $x \leq 5$
d) $2 < x < 7$
e) $x \leq 1$ or $x \geq 3$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) $3 < x < 8$, b) Not AND, c) $0 \leq x \leq 5$, d) $2 < x < 7$, e) Not AND
worked_examples.concept_applied: AND inequalities require both conditions; they can be written in compact form with the variable in the middle.

image.alt: Summary of AND compound inequality basics
image.caption: Figure 6.6.8: AND compound inequalities basics.

sections.introduction: Solving an AND compound inequality means finding all values that satisfy both inequalities simultaneously.

key_concept.definition: To solve an AND compound inequality written in compact form $a < x < b$, we isolate $x$ in the middle by performing the same operations on all three parts. Whatever we do to the middle, we must do to the left and right as well.
key_concept.context: This is like solving two inequalities at once, but working with all three parts simultaneously keeps the work organized.

image.alt: Example: -3 < 2x + 1 < 7 solved step by step
image.caption: Figure 6.6.10: Solving a compact AND inequality.

worked_examples.title: Solving Compact AND Inequalities

image.alt: Compact AND inequalities to solve
image.caption: Figure 6.6.11: Solve each inequality.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each compound inequality and graph the solution:
a) $-3 < 2x + 1 < 7$
b) $4 \leq 3x - 2 \leq 10$
c) $-5 < \frac{x}{2} + 1 < 3$
d) $-2 \leq 4 - 2x \leq 6$

image.alt: Number line: open circles at -2 and 3, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.12: -2 < x < 3.

image.alt: Number line: closed circles at 2 and 4, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.13: 2 ≤ x ≤ 4.

image.alt: Number line: open circles at -12 and 4, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.14: -12 < x < 4.

step_by_step.calculation: Divide all parts by -2 (FLIP inequalities): $3 \geq x \geq -1$ or $-1 \leq x \leq 3$

image.alt: Number line: closed circles at -1 and 3, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.15: -1 ≤ x ≤ 3.

worked_examples.concept_applied: Perform same operation on all three parts. When multiplying/dividing by a negative, flip both inequality signs.

process_flow.description: Recognize if the inequality is in compact form $a < x < b$ or as separate statements.
process_flow.mechanism: If separate, rewrite in compact form if possible.

image.alt: Identifying compact form
image.caption: Figure 6.6.16: Step 1 - Identify form.

process_flow.description: Perform inverse operations on all three parts to get the variable alone in the middle.
process_flow.mechanism: Add/subtract first, then multiply/divide. If multiplying/dividing by a negative, flip both inequality signs.

image.alt: Performing operations on all three parts
image.caption: Figure 6.6.17: Step 2 - Isolate variable.

process_flow.description: Plot the solution on a number line with appropriate circles and shading.
process_flow.mechanism: Open circles for < or >, closed for ≤ or ≥. Shade between the endpoints.

image.alt: Number line with shading between endpoints
image.caption: Figure 6.6.18: Step 3 - Graph solution.

image.alt: Summary of solving AND compound inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.6.19: Solving AND inequalities summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes AND inequalities are written as two separate statements. We solve each separately and then find the intersection.

introduction_image.alt: Two separate inequalities solved then combined
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.6.20: Solving separate AND inequalities.

key_concept.definition: For an AND inequality written as $x > a$ and $x < b$, solve each inequality individually, then find the values that satisfy both. The result is $a < x < b$ (with appropriate endpoint inclusion).
key_concept.context: This method works for any AND combination, even when the inequalities aren't in simple form.

image.alt: Example: 2x + 1 > 5 and 3x - 2 < 7 solved separately
image.caption: Figure 6.6.21: Solving separate inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Solving Separate AND Inequalities

image.alt: Separate AND inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.6.22: Solve each pair.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each compound inequality:
a) $2x + 1 > 5$ and $3x - 2 < 7$
b) $4x - 3 \geq 5$ and $2x + 1 \leq 9$
c) $\frac{x}{2} - 1 < 2$ and $2x + 3 > -1$
worked_examples.concept_applied: Solve each inequality separately, then find the intersection of the solution sets.

image.alt: Summary of solving separate AND inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.6.23: Separate AND inequalities summary.

sections.introduction: Sometimes AND inequalities have no solution or include all real numbers. Understanding these special cases is important.

introduction_image.alt: Special cases: no overlap, all numbers
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.6.24: Special cases in AND inequalities.

key_concept.definition: If the solution sets of the two inequalities do not overlap, the compound inequality has no solution (empty set). If one condition is automatically satisfied by the other, the solution is just the more restrictive condition. If the conditions are contradictory (like $x > 5$ and $x < 2$), there is no solution.
key_concept.context: Recognizing these cases saves time and prevents incorrect answers.

image.alt: Number lines showing no overlap and complete overlap
image.caption: Figure 6.6.25: Special case examples.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Special Cases

image.alt: AND inequalities with special cases
image.caption: Figure 6.6.26: Determine the solution.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each compound inequality:
a) $x > 5$ and $x < 2$
b) $x \geq -3$ and $x \leq 4$
c) $x < 1$ and $x < 3$
d) $x > 2$ and $x > 5$

step_by_step.explanation: No number can be both greater than 5 and less than 2

worked_examples.final_answer: a) No solution, b) $-3 \leq x \leq 4$, c) $x < 1$, d) $x > 5$
worked_examples.concept_applied: When one condition is stricter, it determines the solution. If conditions contradict, no solution.

image.alt: Summary of special cases in AND inequalities
image.caption: Figure 6.6.27: Special cases summary.

sections.introduction: Many real-world situations require satisfying multiple conditions simultaneously, leading to AND compound inequalities.

introduction_image.alt: Real-world AND scenarios: age range, temperature range, budget window
introduction_image.caption: Figure 6.6.28: Real-world AND applications.

key_concept.definition: Real-world AND inequalities arise when a value must fall within a specific range: acceptable temperatures, eligible ages, safe voltage levels, etc. The solution is the interval of values that meet all criteria.
key_concept.context: These problems show how compound inequalities model practical constraints in everyday life.

image.alt: Examples: 18 ≤ age ≤ 65 for employment, 20° ≤ T ≤ 30° for optimal growth
image.caption: Figure 6.6.29: Real-world examples.

worked_examples.title: Eligibility Requirements

image.alt: Age requirement problem
image.caption: Figure 6.6.30: Contest eligibility.

worked_examples.problem: A contest requires participants to be at least 18 years old and no more than 35 years old. Write and solve a compound inequality for eligible ages.

step_by_step.explanation: Eligible ages are from 18 to 35 inclusive

worked_examples.concept_applied: Age ranges are typical AND compound inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Temperature Range for Reaction

image.alt: Chemical reaction temperature
image.caption: Figure 6.6.31: Optimal temperature range.

worked_examples.problem: A chemical reaction proceeds optimally when the temperature is between 20°C and 30°C, inclusive. However, due to equipment limitations, the actual temperature $T$ satisfies $|T - 25| \leq 5$. Does this match the optimal range?
worked_examples.final_answer: Yes, $20 \leq T \leq 30$ matches the optimal range.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Absolute value inequalities often translate to AND compound inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Budget Window

image.alt: Budget range problem
image.caption: Figure 6.6.32: Spending within a range.

worked_examples.problem: You need to spend at least $\$50$ but no more than $\$100$ on groceries. Let $s$ be the amount spent. Write and solve the inequality.
worked_examples.concept_applied: Budget constraints often create AND inequalities.

image.alt: Summary of real-world AND inequality applications
image.caption: Figure 6.6.33: Real-world AND inequalities summary.

sections.section_title: 6.6.6 Common Errors and How to Avoid Them
sections.introduction: Students often make specific mistakes when working with AND compound inequalities. Awareness helps prevent these errors.

classifications.value: When multiplying or dividing by a negative, only flipping one inequality sign.
characteristics: In $-2 < x < 4$, multiplying by -1 incorrectly gives $2 < -x < -4$
Not applying the flip to both inequality signs

image.alt: Correct flip of both signs vs incorrect single flip
image.caption: Figure 6.6.34: Error - forgetting to flip both signs.

examples.explanation: Correct: Divide by -2, flip both: $1.5 > x > -2.5$ or $-2.5 < x < 1.5$

classifications.value: Treating an AND inequality as OR, or vice versa.
characteristics: Writing $x > 2$ or $x < 5$ when AND is intended

image.alt: AND vs OR graphs
image.caption: Figure 6.6.35: Error - confusing AND and OR.

classifications.value: Using wrong circle type on number line graph.
characteristics: Not matching inequality symbol to circle

image.alt: Correct vs incorrect endpoint circles
image.caption: Figure 6.6.36: Error - incorrect endpoint inclusion.

examples.process: Error: Graphing $2 \leq x < 5$ with open circle at 2 and closed at 5

worked_examples.title: Correcting AND Inequality Errors

image.alt: Student's incorrect work
image.caption: Figure 6.6.37: Find and correct errors.

worked_examples.problem: A student solved $-4 < 2 - 3x \leq 5$ and got $2 < x \leq -1$. Identify and correct the error.

step_by_step.explanation: Student got $2 < x \leq -1$, which is impossible

worked_examples.concept_applied: When dividing by a negative in a compound inequality, flip both inequality signs.

image.alt: Summary table of common AND inequality errors and corrections
image.caption: Figure 6.6.38: Common errors summary.

sections.introduction: Apply your skills to solve a variety of AND compound inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Practice Set

image.alt: Multiple practice problems
image.caption: Figure 6.6.39: Practice problems.

worked_examples.problem:
Solve each compound inequality and graph the solution:
1) $-5 < 2x + 1 < 7$
2) $3 \leq 4x - 1 \leq 11$
3) $x - 3 > -2$ and $2x + 1 < 9$
4) $-2 \leq 3 - x \leq 4$
5) $\frac{x}{2} + 1 \geq 0$ and $\frac{x}{3} - 1 \leq 1$
6) Real-world: A parking garage charges $\$5$ for the first hour and $\$3$ for each additional hour. You have $\$20$ and want to park between 3 and 6 hours. Write and solve an inequality for the total cost.

image.alt: Number line: open circles at -3 and 3, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.40: -3 < x < 3.

image.alt: Number line: closed circles at 1 and 3, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.41: 1 ≤ x ≤ 3.

image.alt: Number line: open circles at 1 and 4, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.42: 1 < x < 4.

image.alt: Number line: closed circles at -1 and 5, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.43: -1 ≤ x ≤ 5.

image.alt: Number line: closed circles at -2 and 6, shaded between
image.caption: Figure 6.6.44: -2 ≤ x ≤ 6.

step_by_step.explanation: Cost $C = 5 + 3(h-1)$ for h > 1. For 3 ≤ h ≤ 6, cost range:

worked_examples.concept_applied: Practice solving various AND compound inequalities, including those requiring careful handling of negative coefficients.

image.alt: Complete solutions to practice problems
image.caption: Figure 6.6.45: Practice solutions.

summary: AND compound inequalities require that a value satisfy two conditions simultaneously. They can be written in compact form as $a < x < b$ (or with ≤ or ≥) or as separate statements like $x > a$ and $x < b$. To solve compact AND inequalities, perform the same operation on all three parts—left, middle, and right. When multiplying or dividing by a negative number, remember to flip both inequality signs. For separate AND inequalities, solve each individually and then find the intersection of the solution sets. Special cases include no solution when the conditions contradict (like $x > 5$ and $x < 2$) and cases where one condition is automatically satisfied by the other (like $x < 1$ and $x < 3$ giving $x < 1$). Real-world applications include age ranges, temperature windows, budget constraints, and any situation where a value must fall within a specific interval. Graphing AND inequalities on a number line shows a shaded segment between two endpoints, with open or closed circles indicating whether endpoints are included.

review_questions_image.alt: Comprehensive summary: compact form, solving methods, special cases, real-world applications, graphing
review_questions_image.caption: Figure 6.6.46: AND compound inequalities summary.
